nodes.name: Decision making process
nodes.text:
Decision making process

This element captures how key decisions on the evolution of the bank are reached. These include decisions originating both within the bank itself, and how other stakeholders – government, the private sector and civil society – interact with the bank to influence its future.

Key questions:

  • What is the process to review the performance of the GIB?
  • Is the level of capitalization adequate for the bank’s ongoing activities?
  • How does the bank prioritise new sectors and decide when to exit?
  • How is the bank adjusting to evolving market requirements?
  • How is the GIB aligning with national climate targets?
  • In case of asset sale: What is the sale process of the institution?

nodes.name: Stakeholder engagement
nodes.text:
Stakeholder engagment

This phase involves identifying the stakeholders who will shape the future evolution of the bank. In addition to those within the bank responsible for shaping its direction, stakeholders also include those organisations and institutions responsible for the initial casemaking and design phases of the institution, as well as financial institutions and those in the government responsible for both supervising the GB as well as those shaping government policy.

As the institution increasingly becomes a repository of knowledge and expertise in green issues, exchanges with the government will become increasingly two-way, with GB personnel increasingly informing government policy and decision making.

Key questions:

  • How does the bank consult on future needs/ engage with the real economy and finance sectors?
  • What institutions will shape the evolution of the bank?
  • Will the GB inform government policy as well as vice versa?

nodes.name: Analytical support
nodes.text:
Analytical support

The decision making process for the evolution of the bank requires analytical support to evaluate the available options. This analytical capacity comes from the bank itself, alongside external advisors such as economic consultancies, NGOs and the relevant Government departments.

Key questions:

  • What was its performance? (e.g. market barriers removed?)
  • What is the role of the institution moving forward? How is it aligned with national plans?
  • What is the sectoral landscape and where can the bank have the most impact?
  • Would a broader remit result in higher impact? Should the GIB invest at different levels of the economy?

nodes.name: Standards and frameworks
nodes.text:
Standards and frameworks

In the evolution phase it is important to ensure that the institution is aligned with the best international standards and setting best practices to maintain its green credentials.

Key questions:

  • Are the green principles and remit aligned with best practices?
  • Are there other non-green criteria that need to be included (e.g. social impacts)?

nodes.name: Evolution
nodes.text: The evolution phase represents how a green bank responds to the changing requirements; as the bank breaks down market barriers and introduces private capital, it will need to open up new markets. This phase also captures how the bank responds performance reviews, as well as continuing engagement with the stakeholders -who were key in the casemaking and design phases of the institution.
nodes.output:
Output

The evolution phase yields a series of key outputs which lay the groundwork for the next phase – the process could start again. For reference, a checklist of the outputs of the evolution phase is below. We also include below the specific outputs generated in the UK case – Green Investment Bank.

Future needs of the transition

Level of capital adequacy

  • GIB Board proposals
  • Aldersgate evaluates performance of institution

Performance of the institution.

  • UK Government commissioned study on GIB performance/future
  • Vivid Economics assessed the role of the GIB – commissioned by UK National Infrastructure Commission

State of the market barriers.

  • Consultation by Environmental Audit Committee

Relevance of sectoral priorities.

  • UK Government commissioned study on GIB performance/future
  • Consultation by Environmental Audit Committee

Recapitalization of the institution.

Green criteria and international best practice.
